greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = A006496(n)/2.
comment: Partial sums of A006495. - _Paul Barry_, Mar 16 2006
This is the Lucas U(P=2,Q=5) sequence. - _R. J. Mathar_, Oct 24 2012
With different signs, 0, 1, -2, -1, 12, -19, -22, 139, -168, -359, 1558, ... we obtain the Lucas U(-2,5) sequence. - _R. J. Mathar_, Jan 08 2013
link: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..500
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (2,-5).
formula: G.f.: 1/(4*x - 1/G(0)) where G(k) = 1 - (k+1)/(1 - x/(x - (k+1)/G(k+1) )); (recursively defined continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 06 2012
G.f.: Q(0)*x/2, where Q(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - x*(4*k+2 - 5*x)/( x*(4*k+4 - 5*x) + 1/Q(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Aug 30 2013
maple: seq(coeff(series(x/(1-2*x+5*x^2),x,n+1), x, n), n = 0 .. 30); # _Muniru A Asiru_, Oct 23 2018
program: (Sage) [lucas_number1(n,2,5) for n in range(0, 29)] # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Apr 23 2009
(MAGMA) I:=[0,1]; [n le 2 select I[n] else 2*Self(n-1) - 5*Self(n-2): n in [1..50]]; // _G. C. Greubel_, Oct 22 2018
(GAP) a:=[0,1];; for n in [3..30] do a[n]:=2*a[n-1]-5*a[n-2]; od; a; # _Muniru A Asiru_, Oct 23 2018
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
